Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Effect of Powder Properties and Processing Conditions on the Performance of Pharmaceutical Tablets

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pharmaceutical tablets account for a large fraction of oral solid dosage forms dispensed today. They are traditionally manufactured by directly compressing a blend of the active pharmaceutical ingredient and excipient powders. In spite of its long history, however, product quality control relies extensively on empirical methods. Evaluating the impact of excipient variability on the performance of pharmaceutical tablets, for example, still presents a great challenge. To address these problems, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has released guidelines for the implementation of quality-by-design in the manufacturing process and manufacturers are increasingly focusing on raw materials and process controls. It is therefore of strategic importance to understand the interrelationship between raw material properties and manufacturing process parameters on product quality and performance. The collaborative research effort by researchers at Purdue and Rutgers will combine experiments, simulations and modeling to address this important issue in the case of pharmaceutical tablets manufactured by direct compression of powders. The broad nature of the collaboration also provides an excellent opportunity to train graduate and undergraduate students in engineering and pharmaceutical sciences in a wide range of experimental and computational techniques. The investigators will also engage in outreach efforts coordinated at both universities through different undergraduate research programs. In addition, the numerical methods resulting from the project will be broadly available to the pharmaceutical and process engineering communities and educators through NSF's supported open-access HUBzero platforms, such as pharmaHUB.org.

The intellectual merit of the research work lies in developing a predictive multi-scale model that is based on a mechanistic understanding at the level of individual powder particles and captures the complex interrelationship between powder properties (e.g., wetting) and processing parameters (e.g., compression force) with critical quality attributes of dry tablets (e.g., hardness) and tablet performance (e.g., disintegration behavior in contact with water). The transformative nature of the research includes: (i) A novel mechanistic model of compressed powders under large deformations and high confinement to predict detailed structure and material strength, and a multi-scale approach to describe solvent uptake combined with ad-hoc experiments that decouple the dominant penetration mechanisms (capillary imbibition and case-II diffusion) and is able to describe disintegration behavior; (ii) A broad set of ad-hoc experiments (tablet hardness, free and constrained swelling, column imbibition with multiple fluids) that will allow iterative experiment-model synergy for increasingly complex systems. The model and the set of ad-hoc experiments will then be utilized to reveal and understand the interrelationship between the properties of the raw materials and manufacturing process parameters with the quality and performance of pharmaceutical tablets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pharmaceutical tablets are the most common cost-effectiveness and easy method to administer medication in use today. However, design and product quality control rely extensively on experimental approaches. Often, correlation and causality between ingredients found in the tablet to the drug absorption are lost, and our fundamental understanding of the physical process is still minimal. Therefore, it is of strategic importance to understand the interrelationship between raw material properties and manufacturing process parameters with product quality and performance - drug delivery to the body. A tablet's performance manufactured by direct die compaction of powders is typically characterized by the tablet's strength and the drug release mechanism. Tablet swelling implies that the drug will be released in a diffusion-controlled manner over an extended period. In contrast, tablet disintegration assures that the release is produced much faster as the break-up of a tablet into small particles happens in seconds. Consequently, the medicine is released from much smaller fragments than the full tablet. It is worth noting that die compaction is a synthesis process that converts a loose powder into a solid material. The performance attributes are those of the final product and cannot be further modified during the fabrication process. In this study, we combined experimental methods and numerical models to understanding this interrelationship for tablets manufactured by direct compression of powders. Accomplishing this goal presented significant challenges due to the large variety of powder mixtures. Complex and coupled physics effects arise during the manufacturing processes and when the tablet disintegrates and dissolves upon contact with the body's physiologic fluids. We used a bottom-up approach to tackle such complexity that describes the physics at individual powder particle length scale.

Intellectual Merit: By integrating experiments, modeling and simulations, we developed a novel numerical modeling approach, that sits at the particle scale, to understand the manufacturing process of power compaction. The modeling approach also enables the understanding of water update, tablet swelling and disintegration. A broad set of experiments were developed to successfully validate different aspects of the model. We demonstrated that experiments and numerical models need to be developed in lock-step coordination in order to provide insight into the behavior of complex multi-physics systems.

Broader Impacts: The results of this research have been broadly disseminated in conferences, peer-reviewed publications, and a free compaction virtual tool is available at the nanoHUB platform. This study supported the training of aspiring scientists and engineers in state-of-the-art experimental techniques, fundamental mechanics, computer modeling and simulations, and applied mathematics. We demonstrate that the seamless integration of experimental and computational methods is paramount for advancing the formulation of pharmaceutical solid tablets. The study partially supported the training of 1 post-doctoral scholar, 4 Ph.D. students, 1 MS student, and 5 undergraduate students from Purdue University. Additionally, the partnership with the Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN) at Purdue University allowed 6 undergraduate students from community colleges to be partially supported during their URE at Purdue.
